post.body: Don't be a Windows-Key Libertarian, guys
post.title: The Political Triangle with each corner's extremists labelled

body:
To call this the political triangle would be very very inaccurate

The three corners of the political Trichotomy is labeled Individualism, absolutism and communism. The far right would be between Individualism and absolutism, and fascism would be on the absolutist side between absolutism and communism. Democracy would be in the middle between Individualism and communism.
body_html:
To call this the political triangle would be very very inaccurate

The three corners of the political Trichotomy is labeled Individualism, absolutism and communism. The far right would be between Individualism and absolutism, and fascism would be on the absolutist side between absolutism and communism. Democracy would be in the middle between Individualism and communism.

post.body: Don't be a Windows-Key Libertarian, guys
post.title: The Political Triangle with each corner's extremists labelled

body:
It's partly a reflection on the left-libertarian corner of the traditional political compass. Yes, it's possible to be a bit economically left and a bit libertarian, but you can't be extremely libertarian and extremely left wing at the same time. The more you are one, the less you are the other. So that corner makes less sense the deeper into it you go.

The libertarian corner of the triangle is about freedom, the left-wing corner is about equality, the right-wing corner is about hierarchy (if I recall correctly). Equality and hierarchy are clearly in opposition to each other, and liberty is also in tension with both equality and hierarchy. So I think the triangle makes more sense than the traditional political compass.

The left-libertarian corner of the 2-axis compass is kind of like one of those exotic sub-atomic particles which is predicted to exist, because it's the opposite in charge / spin / whatever of some other particle that's known to exist. But scientists have yet to actually find any...
body_html:
It's partly a reflection on the left-libertarian corner of the traditional political compass. Yes, it's possible to be a bit economically left and a bit libertarian, but you can't be extremely libertarian and extremely left wing at the same time. The more you are one, the less you are the other. So that corner makes less sense the deeper into it you go.

The libertarian corner of the triangle is about freedom, the left-wing corner is about equality, the right-wing corner is about hierarchy (if I recall correctly). Equality and hierarchy are clearly in opposition to each other, and liberty is also in tension with both equality and hierarchy. So I think the triangle makes more sense than the traditional political compass.

The left-libertarian corner of the 2-axis compass is kind of like one of those exotic sub-atomic particles which is predicted to exist, because it's the opposite in charge / spin / whatever of some other particle that's known to exist. But scientists have yet to actually find any...

post.body: Don't be a Windows-Key Libertarian, guys
post.title: The Political Triangle with each corner's extremists labelled

author.bio:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.
author.bio_html:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body:
You're forgetting that the triangle's left and right have nothing to do with how they're used today. Nowadays, especially in the US the left/right axis typically goes from left to libertarian, however what we now call the "right" bears little resemblance to what the term traditionally meant, which was specifically in favor of a defined social structure and hierarchy, ie what AHS thinks everyone to the right of Marx is. The most extreme version of this would be a caste system, not a free market.

I'm no leftist, but I'd probably be more left than right on the triangle if I weren't 100% libertarian, as would almost anyone. Very few people identify with the actual right (I originally made the 2020 chart when I was still figuring out the triangle theory myself, so Republicans are not actually as far right as I put them). You have to remember the key difference, there is communism which is an authoritarian belief that emphasizes 100% equality at all costs, but you cannot deny that there also exists an opposite authoritarian system of hierarchy, elite classes, and leaders. *That* is what the term right-wing meant until very recently, so in order to separate that from the completely unrelated libertarian beliefs you have to have to split it, which creates a triangle. But on the left/right scale people use nowadays I'm probably the most far-right person on this whole site, and people in the right wing of the triangle would probably be considered *left*, so being left or right on the triangle says little about where you are on it.
body_html:
You're forgetting that the triangle's left and right have nothing to do with how they're used today. Nowadays, especially in the US the left/right axis typically goes from left to libertarian, however what we now call the "right" bears little resemblance to what the term traditionally meant, which was specifically in favor of a defined social structure and hierarchy, ie what AHS thinks everyone to the right of Marx is. The most extreme version of this would be a caste system, not a free market.

I'm no leftist, but I'd probably be more left than right on the triangle if I weren't 100% libertarian, as would almost anyone. Very few people identify with the actual right (I originally made the 2020 chart when I was still figuring out the triangle theory myself, so Republicans are not actually as far right as I put them). You have to remember the key difference, there is communism which is an authoritarian belief that emphasizes 100% equality at all costs, but you cannot deny that there also exists an opposite authoritarian system of hierarchy, elite classes, and leaders. That is what the term right-wing meant until very recently, so in order to separate that from the completely unrelated libertarian beliefs you have to have to split it, which creates a triangle. But on the left/right scale people use nowadays I'm probably the most far-right person on this whole site, and people in the right wing of the triangle would probably be considered left, so being left or right on the triangle says little about where you are on it.

body:
Ben Shapiro would likely fall somewhere in the blue section (despite claiming the libertarian label), though not too extreme. Probably about where Trump is now, and both Trump and the Republican party should be moved closer to the center (and Trump should be a tiny bit less auth).

I can't say for Jordan Peterson though.
